Introduction

Leuprolide is a synthetic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist (ie, GnRH analogue) used to modulate the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis.  It functions by initially stimulating, then profoundly suppressing, pituitary gonadotropic secretion (eg, LH, FSH) with continuous administration.  This results in decreased production of gonadal sex steroids (testosterone in men, estradiol in women), leading to a reversible hypogonadal state.

HPG axis physiology



The HPG axis is a hormonal feedback loop that regulates reproductive function in men and women (

figure 1
).  At puberty, the hypothalamus begins periodic, pulsatile releases of GnRH, which stimulate the pituitary to release the gonadotropins LH and FSH, which act on the gonads.



  • In women, this stimulates the ovary to release estrogen and progesterone, which regulate follicular development, the uterine endometrium, and menses (
    figure 2
    ).
  • In men, LH stimulates testicular Leydig cells to produce testosterone, and FSH stimulates testicular Sertoli cells to secrete androgen-binding peptide, which concentrates testosterone in the seminiferous tubules and supports spermatogenesis (
    figure 3
    ).


Pulsatile GnRH maintains physiologic gonadotropin secretion.  However, continuous GnRH receptor stimulation results in the downregulation of GnRH receptors, leading to decreased LH and FSH secretion and, subsequently, suppression of gonadal steroidogenesis.  This pharmacologic principle underlies the therapeutic use of leuprolide and other GnRH agonists.

Mechanism of action



Leuprolide and other GnRH agonists mimic endogenous GnRH but are more potent and have longer half-lives.  They are administered continuously for a prolonged duration, causing 2 effects on the HPG axis that can be divided into 2 phases:



  • With initial use, GnRH agonists stimulate the HPG axis through continuous receptor stimulation, causing increased gonadotropin and sex hormone release with unchanged, normal GnRH levels within the first 1-2 weeks.
  • With prolonged use, GnRH agonists cause desensitization and downregulation of pituitary GnRH receptors, which lead to decreased gonadotropin and sex hormone levels and inhibition of endogenous GnRH release.


The result is hypogonadotropic (ie, low FSH and LH) hypogonadism (ie, low estrogen, low testosterone).  When the agonist is withdrawn, endogenous GnRH pulsations resume, leading to restoration of the HPG axis.

Indications



Leuprolide is used in a wide range of clinical scenarios in which suppression of gonadal hormones is therapeutic:



  • Uterine fibroids (leiomyomas):  GnRH agonists decrease uterine and fibroid volume and blood loss from heavy menstrual bleeding (ie, increase hemoglobin levels).  It is most often used as a bridge therapy to definitive surgical management (eg, myomectomy, hysterectomy) (
    figure 4
    ).
  • Endometriosis:  GnRH agonists reduce endometrial implants and pain.  It is often used in endometriosis after failure of first-line therapies.
  • Central precocious puberty:  GnRH agonists inhibit premature activation of the HPG axis through continual stimulation, allowing for normal and age-appropriate pubertal development.
  • Infertility:  GnRH agonists prevent a premature LH surge during controlled ovarian hyperstimulation.
  • Transgender care:  GnRH agonists can be used in transgender adolescents to suppress endogenous puberty or in adults to reduce endogenous sex hormone levels prior to initiation of cross-sex hormone therapy.


  • Prostate cancer:  GnRH agonists result in testosterone suppression, which slows the progression of androgen-sensitive malignancies.

Adverse effects



Leuprolide's adverse effects are related to its hormonal effects and the induction of a hypogonadal state.

Common adverse effects



  • Hypoestrogenic symptoms in women (eg, vaginal dryness, hot flashes, sleep disturbances).
  • Erectile dysfunction in men.
  • Decreased libido.
  • Fatigue, mood changes (particularly new or worsening depression).

Long-term adverse effects



The long-term effects of GnRH agonists typically limit the duration of therapy.  These include:



  • Low bone density/osteoporosis:  The suppression of estrogen in women and testosterone in men (aromatized to estrogen in men) leads to decreased bone mineral density.  Women with accelerated bone density loss in their 20s and 30s have a significantly higher risk for osteoporosis later in life.  Men undergoing treatment for ≥18 months for prostate cancer are also at risk for accelerated bone loss, which can lead to osteoporosis.
  • Metabolic changes:  GnRH agonist therapy is linked to an increased risk for diabetes mellitus, myocardial infarctions, and strokes in men receiving treatment for prostate cancer.  These findings likely reflect compounded risk in this population, given their age and gender.

Treatment considerations



  • Flare effect:  Women initiating treatment for endometriosis pain or fibroids may initially have worsening pain or bleeding due to the initial increase in estrogen with GnRH agonist treatment.  However, continuous administration ultimately results in estrogen suppression (
    figure 5
    ).  This effect can also be seen in men undergoing treatment for prostate cancer.  The initial rise or "flare" of testosterone may stimulate tumor growth or worsen tumor-related symptoms (eg, bone pain, urinary obstruction).  Because of this, antiandrogens (eg, flutamide) are often added to the initial treatment regimen.
  • Bone density loss:  The concern for accelerated bone loss in young women is the treatment-limiting factor.  GnRH agonist therapy is limited to 6 months in young women; this treatment can be extended to 1 year if add-back therapy (exogenous estrogen/progesterone administration that can offset some of the effects of estrogen suppression without worsening disease symptoms) is used.  Older men undergoing ≥18 months of treatment for prostate cancer should have a baseline DXA scan with repeated screening every 2 years.

Summary



Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist that exerts its therapeutic effects by downregulating pituitary GnRH receptors and suppressing gonadotropin secretion.  This leads to profound reductions in circulating testosterone and estradiol levels.  It has broad clinical utility in hormone-dependent conditions such as prostate cancer, endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and central precocious puberty, as well as in gender-affirming protocols.
